One person starts writing on google docs. before submitting for review, assign to people with questions. get to a point where comments are resolved. trigger big meeting w/ vp eng etc. usually open to everyone. big meeting with lots of people. read through the doc in the meeting. questions get added to the doc in real-time. After the meeting, resolve final. ask for sign off from vp. Adjust formatting and paste into confluence.

How things move from idea to approved/implemented Outer sphere -- distill and classify among customer facing person (support) Review by product management in triage twice a week Prioritize and map to release Add to feature list EMs do effort estimates Take back to PdM Short list is assigned to engineers for release time-frame. RFC goes for review, implementation goes in

The worst feature in slack is their search. Nothing too sophisticated is being done to each message. You often have to sort through 100s of messages. Many thousands of messages.

They (task tools) all do a subset of what you want to do.
Outcome of eng culture run by exec, and the people were hired based on their kaggle scores. Placed into the wrong role -- running production systems.

It was a nightmare to get back to, after being out. And he misses stuff. Have to eyeball it, still. The other EM does the same thing. But even worse, scans multiple times a day. Jeff tells people, if there’s no DM on Slack - don’t expect an answer. Slack is basically a curated email for Jeff.
“Organizational complexity” grows over time - more and more tools gets implemented.

Data scientist really wanted to use Spark and Cassandra (but didn’t really understand both). Ended up with inconsistent data store. Consequence: every month insurance company needs to publish its yellow book which is super important for regulatory -- ended up off by $100M
Often use google cloud search But gets reminded about confluence and other places.
Lots on wiki - people (hr) team use this. 75% is in google docs.

The shortlist of features for a release, the engineers write an RFC. And should be backed by a PRD, if it is a large feature. Before the engineers starts working, the PRD is circulated. Moves to the larger RFC list (just legacy - mostly not commented, but a way to share with sales team). Mitchell and Armand (hashicorp founders) would still be commenting on RFCs. All documents lives in google docs. When you distribute that - you just send to an email list with a link? Yes - a google group with the RFC number in the title.

Can you tell us how ideas mature through your systems? HashiCorp fosters a good environment for this. It is an engineering first company and the opinions on those ideas. If it is a product idea, it would be brought up during a leadership meeting. They meet weekly. Brings in features/bugs from the last week. Decides whether they have to deal with now or later. Feature X starts in this way.
Also use Trello.
When sorting through messages and mails after being out, hard to know what is actually important.
Instead of copying into asana, he created a new org in GH. Created labels and used kanban labeling p0 (next release) to p3 (not planned in a release).

From a development point of view, you get isolation and sometimes you need that as an engineer. To focus and find your flow. But nerding out on something with your neighbor (socialization) is also important.

When Jeff joined HashiCorp, there wasn’t a VP of product (or product organization). There wasn’t a systematic way to get features into the product. No predetermined way to get features into a road map. When Jeff came in, he asked for estimates for features. Usually, he would pull in a team into a room and do feature estimates. Would come out with t-shirt sizes or story points. And could then figure out how much time they actually had to implement. At HashiCorp, he created a spreadsheet to deal with this and gave the team a deadline. 12 hours later, there were threads and comments on each features. Debating the sizes, etc. What would have been synchronous just happened overnight. He would do this again - as people can work on it when it works for them.

Product Management? Use Asana. Working on issues in Jira for Vault. Working with another EM, trying to agree on the system to use. Was on a call with PdMs recently, said “his team will work on PRs and GH Issues”. The PdMs who looks at non-quick-fix bugs and features. They wired 600 tickets by hand from one to the other. (Using Zapier - said it didn’t support it).

PRDs are the most flat structure - just a doc. Nothing stands out when it comes to collaboration. It is usually short and tells us where we are going. Great for alignment between teams. Sometimes I don’t understand everything - when written by engineers. UX is usually not a part of making the PRD (we get called in late in the process). But recently could be involved in the PRD and gave LGTM on the doc.
